thread.title_full: Norway Junk Bond Investors Losing Hope as Oil Squeeze Deepens - Bloomberg Business

author: Jonas Cho Walsgard
title: Norway Junk Bond Investors Losing Hope as Oil Squeeze Deepens
text:
Investors are losing hope in the Norwegian high-yield debt market, according to DNB ASA, the nation’s biggest bank.
A renewed crude plunge has once again ratcheted up risks in market and the longer the situation lasts the “more investors lose hope that companies will be able to serve their debt,” Magnus Vie Sundal, credit analyst at DNB, said in a phone interview Tuesday.
There are “too many rigs and ships compared with demand from oil companies,” he said. “And with this overcapacity comes large debt burdens for oil service providers, for many, too high relative to earnings.”
The Norwegian junk bond market came to a standstill last year as crude prices collapsed. After a slow pick-up in the first half of the year, energy bonds again plunged in August as oil prices reached six-year lows. The DNB High-Yield Norway Total Return Hedged Index fell 4 percent in August.
Oil service companies such as rig-owner Seadrill Ltd. are delaying deliveries and others such as Aker Solutions ASA are cutting jobs to cope with slowdown. Producers including Statoil ASA are cutting investments, triggering more than 20,000 jobs cuts in western Europe’s biggest crude producer.
Even though spreads have widened, offering larger returns for oil-related debt, DNB is keeping its negative outlook for the industry.
“We think these relatively small oil price changes, $40 or $50 a barrel, don’t change the immediate outlook for the companies,” he said. “Many companies must restructure their debt.”
In August there were no new bond issues in the Norwegian high yield market. While the market is “close to impossible” for oil service companies, the primary market for other issuers is open, according to DNB.
“At some point people must start to invest,” he said. “We have redemptions and investors get money back from bond loans maturing. We think the primary market for non-oil related high-yield will wake up again now in September, October, but it will be will be calm, not that many deals.”
